Recommendations for improvement routinely come from safety meetings, equipment inspections, technology improvements and employee suggestions. Shells emergency action plan contains detailed spill, injury, fire, and other emergency response procedures as well as the performance of emergency training, evacuation, and notification. The emergency action plan includes instructions to be followed in the event of an emergency situation (e.g., fire, hazardous material spill, injury), and lists the telephone numbers of agencies and individuals that are to be contacted in the event of an emergency situation. The agencies and individuals to be contacted include emergency responders (e.g., Fire Department/Haz Mat Team) and internal plant contacts (e.g., Plant Manager). Decisions regarding the appropriate level of public notification and CCHSD coordination will be made according to the following protocol:
	
1.	The Production Team Lead/Supervisor (PTL) will determine the level of the incident.
   a.	If the incident is a Contra Costa County Health Services Level 2, the PTL will notify the Plant Manager or Operations Manager or HSSE to help determine whether to order a shelter-in-place (SIP) depending upon wind direction, the type of release, and whether the downwind public could be impacted.
   b.	If the incident is a Contra Costa County Health Services Level 3, the PTL will inform the Plant Manager or Operations Manager or HSSE that they will be notifying CCHSD to sound the Community Warning System (CWS) siren. 
   c.	The PTL will then call CCHSD and advise them to sound the CWS siren.
2.	The PTL will update CCHSD at least once per hour for Level 2 (which requires a SIP), or a Level 3 until plant management arrives.
3.	If a Unified Incident Command is created, the PTL will take the lead with CCHSD until relieved by a plant management representative.
4.	If no Unified Incident Command is created, the PTL will have responsibility to communicate with CCHSD until relieved by a plant management representative.

****THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
	
Shells emergency response program was developed to comply with Title 19 of California Code of Regulations (T19 CCR§2731, AB2185 Business Plan) and emergency action plan requirements under Title 8 of California Code of Regulations (T8 CCR§3220, HAZWOPER standard). Shell has coordinated emergency response plans with local officials and satisfies the requirements of Section 2735.4(c)(3) of the CalARP regulation. 
	
Shell has developed the emergency response program to minimize the effects of accidental releases of hazardous compounds to employees. Computer dispersion modeling, along with using the EPAs RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance document, has demonstrated that worst-case releases of aqueous ammonia would not impact any public receptor.  
	
In 2015, Shell created an on-site, fully functional employee staffed Hazardous Material Emergency Response Team (ERT). All members of the ERT are trained as HAZWOPER Level 3 Technicians. All Operators, Shipping, and Maintenance workers who are not on the ERT are trained as HAZWOPER First Responder Operations Level 2 and can help with any hazardous material emergency response but are considered non-responders and cannot enter the Exclusion Zone.  Large scale emergency response scenarios involving a release of aqueous ammonia (or any other hazardous material) may be coordinated with Contra Costa County Health Services Hazardous Materials or Contra Costa Country Fire Department Hazardous Material personnel and/or outside emergency response contractors. ****THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 
	
Shell has not had any accidental releases involving aqueous ammonia or other extremely hazardous substances that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage during the five-year period since the issuing of the previous RMP submittal. 
	
There has been one accidental release of ammonia at the facility within the most recent five-year period. It occurred on May 7, 2020. A truck tanker offloading hose had a small minor leak at the truck during filling of the main tank. Rather than stopping the offloading, the driver tried fix the leak by adjusting the cam locks while still actively pumping material to the tank. This made the leak worse and was detected by the operator, who noticed a slight ammonia smell during routine rounds.  The operator immediate stopped the offload. The driver was not exposed or hurt, but it resulted in a release of 30 gallons of 29% ammonia solution into the offloading bay and secondary containment. The hose connection was repaired prior to restarting the offload. The event was reviewed with the delivery company, but ultimately resulted in no changes to any procedures, since the driver did not follow both the plants and his own companys offloading procedures. Consequence management for the driver was performed by the delivery company.  
	
This five-year accident history review satisfies the requirements of Section 2750.9 of the CalARP regulation. The purpose of conducting an accidental release review is to promote an informed community while also documenting accidental releases are investigated and concrete changes are made to protect against reoccurrence.

Procedures
	
Written procedures for aqueous ammonia and other bulk liquids are located in the H2 Plant Operating Procedures. Procedures include handling, off-loading, and tank line-up for ammonia service.
	
**Maintenance
	
Shell has a preventive maintenance/inspection program established for process equipment and tanks. Ultrasonic thickness (UT) testing is conducted on the AST on a regular basis. The passive mitigation vapor suppression balls are evaluated annually and replaced if necessary. Shells maintenance department conducts preventive maintenance to assure mechanical integrity of the AST and associated pumps. 
	
**Compliance Audits
	
Shell's Management System includes a compliance auditing component made up of internal compliance audits by the local site and the Catalyst Business, as well as external assessments by Shells Corporate auditing group. HSSE performance compliance issues are documented and require prompt follow up with action plans to prevent reoccurrence.
	
**Emergency Procedures
	
Emergency procedures have been established at Shell Pittsburg. These include response and management of any accidental release and/or injury that may pose an impact to the community. These procedures are included in the Hazardous Material Business Plan (HMBP) submission annually. In 2015, the site established a fully functioning Hazardous Material Emergency Response Team and is now a responding facility. Emergency response activities for RMP/CalARP and other hazardous materials may be handled internally with the Shell Pittsburg Emergency Response Team or can be coordinated with the Contra Costa County Hazardous Material Team, the Contra Costa Fire Department Hazardous Material Team or the San Ramon Valley Hazardous Material Team. Emergency response activities for medical, rescue and other emergencies are also coordinated with Contra Costa Fire Department Station 86, located two blocks from the facility. **Training
	
To ensure that processes are operated by competent individuals, training is a key component of Shells Management System. Initial training is given to employees at the time of hire. Subsequent training is given when there has been a change to relevant systems. On-the-job-training qualification is required for each operator. 
	
**Incident Investigation
	
Each HSSE incident or near-miss incident involving an RMP/CalARP material is analyzed and evaluated to determine the underlying cause(s). A Root Cause Analysis (RCA) is conducted and appropriate corrective actions to prevent recurrence are determined.  Risk analysis is used to prioritize established actions, and records are maintained to track these actions to completion.
	
**Process Safety Information
	
Shell maintains copies of all SDS for all raw materials and substances used at the facility. A list of maximum inventory and largest container sizes for all regulated substances is maintained. SDS and inventory data is updated as necessary. SDS are maintained electronically on the Shell Healths website OneSDS. All employees and contractors with Shell computer access can use OneSDS. One set of SDS hard copies are maintained in the HSSE Department. Inventory information (i.e., Business Plan) is maintained at the HSSE Department. 
	
**Process Hazard Review/Hazard Control Sheets
	
As part of the Management of Change procedures at the facility, safety and operating hazards are evaluated for new or modified equipment. Appropriate personnel involved with the equipment operation, maintenance and safety participate in the hazard review which are documented on Hazard Control Sheets. The review is designed to identify the hazards of the process, possible equipment failures, and safeguards to prevent failures or errors. Results of the hazard review, along with any design changes identified as a result of the hazard review, are incorporated into the project.

**Pre-Startup Safety Review
	
As part of the MOC process, Shell requires that new or modified process equipment meet all design requirements prior to operation. This review includes updating P&IDs, employee and contractor training, documenting Operating, Maintenance, Safety and Emergency procedures, environmental permits, chemical information (including safety data sheets [SDS]), and information on technology or equipment.
	
**Contractors
	
Shells contractor management program requires the HSSE Department and the Contract Owner review each contractor to ensure they meet established safety criteria. All contractors are required to complete training on the hazards and emergency response activities at the facility prior to starting work. Contractor activities are monitored to verify safe work practices and appropriate training. 
	
**Safety Work Permits/Hot Work Permits/Confined Space Permits 
	
All project and maintenance work requires use of a work permit process. This includes safe work permits for general work, hot work permits for sparking or open flame work, and confined space permits for entries. Each Safe Work Permit identifies the work to be performed, equipment involved, precautions to be taken, dates, and authorized signatures. For Hot Work Permits, fire prevention measures are also included. Shell staffs an Emergency Response Team, which is trained in confined space rescue, hazardous materials response, use of fire extinguishers, and basic medical/first aid. The ER Team must be present during all confined space entries. Copies of all permits are maintained.

This document presents the five-year update for the Risk Management Plan (RMP) dated April 2017, presented to the Contra Costa County Health Services Department (CCCHSD), for the Shell (formerly Criterion) Catalysts & Technologies L.P. (Shell) facility located at 2840 Willow Pass Road in Bay Point, California.  It fulfills the requirements to submit an RMP under the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program. Shell qualifies for Program Level 1 under the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP and CalARP regulations.

This RMP update summarizes the accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at Shell that minimize the publics exposure to regulated substances used at the facility.  Included is a description of the hypothetical worst-case accidental release of 19,250 gallons of aqueous ammonia (29% maximum concentration) from an above-ground storage tank (AST). The process for which aqueous ammonia is used is also presented.  Passive mitigation equipment has been installed around the AST to minimize the surface area for evaporation during a spill.
